ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I would take "agriculture" out of the name of the course. This is all about wine, specifically. It seemed like the assignments, for many groups, took much longer than necessary. I think people didn't expect to have to spend as much time working of some of the group projects.

The teacher doesn't like giving long lectures and generally prefers group assignments and discussions (which are great), but he is a actually a great lecturer, so he should spend some time doing that too. Also because most of the class didn't have any background knowledge on the wine industry the lectures were very helpful.

As a non-SOM student, I was hoping to get a true education in intro to responsible business. However, rather than being taught skills, we were made to learn on our own in groups which I did not find effective. The business students in my group homework often took over the responsibilities of the business analyses, so I did not learn these. I did not find effective the in-class group projects either--I would have preferred to learn directly from the professor. Overall the group assignments and non-instruction classes were too many. The workload was pushed too far to the end and each assignment was very demanding, and I did not feel I had been taught the skills or knowledge to complete them.
A field trip would have been useful. Less valuable skills (material on sustainability basics) than the oil and gas version.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: I learned a lot about the wine business and sustainability issues/practices within the industry, which was very interesting to me. The assignments helped with learning more about actual wineries.

The depth into which we explored wine operations. Iluminating the difficulties with understanding "value"...the nebulous-ness of the idea is very challenging, especially when using dollars as a measure. The nature of the beast, I suppose. Its good to be able to see the realities of the challenges.
the topics
The assignments and class discussions were fun and very interesting. It was also really nice to learn something completely different from our other courses.

-Quantitative skills learned for quantifying sustainability initiatives -Analyzing companies based on their public information to assess sustainability relative to industry -Understanding how agriculture does sustainability -Guest lectures were insightful and ecouraging, as I was able to see how sustainability is addressed In Practice; particularly Diagio Breweries & _____Family Wines guests - In class activities were a nice way to break up lecture; keep doing that, but maybe make groups smaller or only have students presents in class at alternating intervals/randomly 50% of groups present...to allow smaller groups, but not affect presentation time.
I enjoyed the panel of speakers and learning about wine production.
Todd Cort is an excellent teacher!
Todd is very passionate and knowledgeable about the material.
The wine tastings (opportunity to taste new wines from unfamiliar areas), lectures focusing on operational aspects of wineries

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I thought that the assignments were less explained than in the oil and gas half of the class, and I think that the calendar schedule of the class made completing the assignments more difficult. I would have like to have had more time in class understanding what the professor expected out of the deliverables.
Group work in class could be valuable, but it is also easy for people to "hide" during those activities.
the assignment timing

My only suggestion is for us to have more time for assignments since we had to rush a lot in the end. For example, it would be better in my opinion to cancel the true value assignment (or do a in class exercise) and spend that extra time on the business plan.

-smaller groups in class -The end of the semester was a little chaotic; assignments were on top of each other --though we voted for that. Still let students vote. It was busy but I am glad we did not delay presentations/final assignments.

More instruction and less group work. Less intense workload would make it more educational; the size of each assignment meant dividing up group work rather than working on it together, diminishing the educational value of working in a group.
Projects should be more spread out.

There were WAY too many in class group projects. I got far less out of those exercises than I did when Todd would just lecture. To make in class group exercises work more smoothly they need to be very focused and with a lot of assumptions already made so that we can go deeper into a single topic instead of superficially through a spectrum of topics. I got more from doing the group projects as an entire class. IT kept us more focused on the topic.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Way outside of my main course of study at FES, so this added a valuable perspective that I think really enhances my experience at the tree school up the hill.
i just wanted to take the class
This course was very new to me since I don't have any business or corporate background. Since I'm here to learn new skills this was great.

I want to go into environmental consulting or CSR team management --this content was critical. It seems less than 3 classes at Yale address sustainable business so directly while maintaining "practical" skill building. Hard balance to strike.
Loved the focus on the wine industry, since there are very few classes focusing on agriculture/ food.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I am interested in environmental sustainability and how it is addressed/applied in the private sector.
Getting an SOM-type perspective on issues that have a large impact on sustainable operations.
The topic
To learn about corporate sustainability and how businesses deal with environmental issues.
Was hoping to learn skills and applied knowledge about business considerations for the agricultural sector.
For the sustainable wine industry focus.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: I felt that the wine and agriculture half of the class was not as well run as the oil and gas half, but it was the topics in the second half were still interesting.
I came in wanting to have an applied version of CSR practices, not just the concepts, so it was very valuable to see an application of the process.
yes
Yes1 Very much.
Yes.
No; I do not feel I gained many skills.
Yes, learned so much more than I expected to for a half semester course.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I thought that group work made was necessary because the assignments were very long, but that it was a disadvantage to the class to have to do group work because I only thoroughly learned about the parts of assignments that I personally completed. I think that future assignments could be a bit shorter and have more guidance, so that they could be completed independently or with a group of just two or three, and that would make the assignments more valuable to the class.

It can be very frustrating when people prioritize work differently, and tend to want to do the bulk of the work near the end of the deadline. This is very different from my methods. It was a challenge, and always is/will be.
Great to combine the different skills Very time intensive to meet with the whole group over and over again
Group projects are very hard to deal with generally. I was lucky my group worked well together for the most part, but for the one project the teacher chose our groups for us it was terrible.

I learned some from my teammates in terms of business language and concepts, but the downside is that group assignments (especially when large) often mean dividing up work rather than working on it together, diminishing the educational value of working in a group. i.e., a business student went off and created a waterfall chart, so I did not learn how to do so, and it was not something we learned from the instructor.
There were very few advantages to working in groups. Assignments would have been much better done independently, or collaboratively. However, the assignments are too long to do on our own.
Great team!

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Come into the class with some understanding of metrics and CSR tools, and look to apply that knowledge to this specific sector. I would recommend either taking the metrics course prior to this, or have some experience with the concepts the shorten your catch up time as we skip through some of the jargon during class.
Take it!
If you like group work, discussions and creative assignments go for it!
Great class, be prepared to do most of the work at the end of the semester.
